oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Albany, New York, A Bicentennial of Albany Views: 1963-1967 and 1974-1975 Compared
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An album of photographs of the area around Clinton Avenue, Broadway, North Pearl Street, and Quackenbush Street in Albany before and after the urban renewal work of the 1960s and 1970s. Multiple photographs of the same location from different vantage points appear in the book. Many of the pictures overlap and compliment each other. The album was created by Florence L. Powell, a Historical Research Assistant for the Department of Human Resources in the City of Albany in 1976. Powell took all the photographs and made five copies of the album. This is copy number two, the personal copy of John J. McEneny.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Powell, Florence L.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Albany, New York, Construction of the New York State Captiol
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of the construction of the New York State Capitol. A description on the back of the picture reads: Supt'd John Bridgeford seated in buggy in foreground. Old houses in State St, Capitol Pl, Congress St, and Washington Ave now razed are shown in picture. In the bottom right of the photograph, in handwriting it reads: No. 5. Sept 6th 1869 1.10 pm. Although it is hard to tell, white and African-American workers appear to be shown. In the middle of the picture, an pulley system is being used by workers to lift stone while men in suits look on.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Albany, New York, View Toward Swan St from Capitol Park
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photo of an area that is now part of Capitol Park looking toward Swan Street between State Street and Washington Avenue. The row of houses and apartment buildings shown are where the Alfred E. Smith Building now stands. The Ft. Frederick Apartments, visible on the right at the corner of Swan St and Washington Ave, were moved to State St when the Alfred E Smith Building was built. The spires of the Westminster Presbyterian Church and the Emmanuel Baptist Church are visible. Parked cars are visible at the edge of the park along Swan St and pedestrians are shown crossing the park.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Albany, New York, New York State Education Department Building Construction
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The State Education Building is located on Washington Ave. between Hawk and Swan St. The New York State Department of Education Building was begun in 1908 and completed in 1912. It was designed by architect Henry Hornbostel and was the first major building constructed in the United States solely as a headquarters for the administration of education. (from the National Register of Historic Places application).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Albany, New York, Albany-Greenbush Bridge
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of the Albany-side entrance to the Greenbush Bridge. Cars can be seen passing under the overpass (originally intended for train travel) that reads Hudson Bridge. Powerlines for electricity and trolley cars, cobblestone streets, and trolley tracks are all visible. A woman pushing a baby carriage and two children are crossing the street on the left. A large painted Coca-Cola sign is visible on the side of a building on the left side of the photograph. 3 pedestrians can be seen crossing the bridge on foot.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bridges
Bridges; Photographs;
Transportation
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: B & W print mounted on cardboard; cardboard 9.5 x 12 in. (24.13 x 30.48 cm.); print 8 x 10 in. (20.32 x 25.4 cm.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: From Crossing the Hudson: Historic Bridges and Tunnels of the River by Donald E. Wolf (Rivergate Books, 2010): The third Albany-Greenbush Bridge is show here as it appeared during the early 1930s. Note that its upper level, built to accommodate rail travel, has not been extended because no railroad ever used the bridge. The Parker Dunn Memorial Bridge is now located where the Albany-Greenbush Bridge once crossed the Hudson.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Albany, New York, 1936 Flooding on the Hudson River in Albany
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph looking south showing the flooding that occurred on the Hudson River at Albany in March 1936. The Delaware and Hudson Railroad Building (now the SUNY System Administration Building) is visible in the bottom right of the photograph. The Greenbush Bridge is also visible. The roofs of buildings along the river are visible above the waterline, one has a sign that reads Night Line New York. Father inland are railroad tracks, with people and cars visible on the streets on the west side of the tracks.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Floods; Floods--New York (State); Hudson River (N.Y. and N.J.)
Photographs; Floods - New York - Albany
Environment & Nature;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: B & W print mounted on cardboard; cardboard 9.5 x 12 in. (24.13 x 30.48 cm.); print 9.5 x 6.8 in. (24.1 x 17.5 cm.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: March 12 -18, 1936 (Some consider two events) - Major flooding throughout the Northeast as a result of extremely heavy snowpack and a double dose of spring rains. Caused highest stages on Hudson at Troy (29.5 ft.) and Albany (17.9 ft.) since completion of Conklingville Dam (from Weather.gov).
